Award.AwardTitle: Travel support for invited speakers to attend 86th ACS Colloid and Surface Science Symposium at Johns Hopkins University, June 10-13, 2012

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1201597
PI: Bevan

This award will partially cover travel costs associated with invited speakers attending the 86th ACS Colloid and Surface Science Symposium at Johns Hopkins University, June 10-13, 2012. Invited speaker participation is critical to the meeting's success in terms of attracting the best contributed talks and exposing graduate student attendees to the state of the art in the fields of colloid and surface science.

The intellectual merit of the 2012 colloid and surface science symposium at Johns Hopkins University is that it provides a forum for communicating fundamentally new insights into colloidal and surface science with relevance to existing complex fluids and advanced materials applications as well as emerging nano- and bio- technologies. Due to its broad scope, this meeting typically attracts 500-700 attendees from diverse disciplines (e.g. Chemistry, Chemical Engineering, Materials Science, Physics, etc.) and nearly all major US academic institutions and many leading international institutions. The diversity of the attendees and the talks is further represented by contributions from theoretical, computational, and experimental groups and the participation of scientists and engineers from all sectors including industry, government, and academia. This symposium provides an opportunity for all attendees, including graduate students, to disseminate their own research findings and to learn about the latest work of invited plenary and keynote speakers who represent the best internationally recognized investigators working on problems involving colloid and surface science and engineering.

The broader impacts of this proposal are that funds from the NSF will be used to ensure the participation and attendance of premier researchers at our symposium, and thus guarantee dissemination of state-of-the-art research to all attendees as well as an impact on the education and training of graduate student attendees. This meeting has traditionally been a good forum for graduate students, and we expect that about a quarter of the meeting attendees will be graduate students presenting oral presentations or posters on their PhD projects. By acquiring travel support the best domestic and international speakers, this support is in line with NSF's mission to disseminate research findings from NSF supported research and educate and train students to create tomorrow's high tech work force. The requested funds will support invited speaker travel via reduced registration costs so they can participate in the meeting with preference given to groups traditionally under-represented in science and engineering discipline.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 86th American Chemical Society Colloid and Surface Science Symposium was held at the Homewood campus of Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, Maryland from June 10-13, 2012. The Symposium was co-organized by Professors Michael Bevan and Joelle Frechette of Johns Hopkins University. There were a couple initiatives at this meeting including the Langmuir student award session, free registration for all organizers and keynote speakers, and reduced rates for students and postdocs. The meeting included 536 attendees, 464 oral presentations, 49 posters, 4 plenary lectures, 13 technical symposia, and participants from 186 institutions and 18 countries.

Two plenary lectures and two award lectures were presented as part of the meeting. All were held in Shriver Hall in the engineering quad with an approximate capacity of 700 people. The symposia topics were chosen to be representative of the fundamental topics covered at past colloids meetings. The oral sessions were held in three adjacent buildings in the engineering quad of the Johns Hopkins Homewood campus. All symposia were well-supported during abstract submission. A total of 513 papers were presented at the meeting: 464 oral (including four plenary and award lectures) and 49 posters. Each symposium had two co-organizers. One organizer was from industry, one was from a government lab, two were alumni of JHU, 9 were professors at JHU, and 19 were from institutions other than JHU. Each technical symposium featured two invited keynote speakers.

The intellectual merit of this meeting is that it provided a forum for communicating fundamentally new insights into colloidal and surface science with relevance to existing complex fluids and advanced materials applications as well as emerging nano- and bio- technologies. The broader impact of this funding is that it ensured the participation and attendance of premier researchers at our symposium, and thus supported dissemination of state-of-the-art research to all attendees as well as an impact on the education and training of graduate student attendees.
